Could you please confirm "mocha" should remain untranslated?

data.title: json enum hover: prepend enum value name to enum value description
data.body:
Using "enumDescription" shows up as a second line of the enum hover, which makes it a bit difficult to understand what is what:

![2017-02-09_16-33-51](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/22790214/c148b808-eee5-11e6-8015-1283e79e2e59.png)

If I prepend the enum value's name, it is better readable:

![2017-02-09_16-34-36](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/22790221/c4f50dee-eee5-11e6-83ea-7d6c60b70b1d.png)

Now when using IntelliSense the name is duplicated which looks bad and results in truncation:

![2017-02-09_16-35-10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/22790226/c7da2e22-eee5-11e6-99bb-d0f26d448961.png)

I suggest that the hover prepends the enum value name automatically, so that the enumDescription does not have to do it.

data.title: Test: debug view sizes
data.body:
- [x] Any os @rebornix
- [x] Any os @kieferrm 

Complexity: 1

We have fine tuned the sizes of debug views in the debug viewlet. Verify:
* Breakpoint view always has the exact size of the number of breakpoints up to a maximum size
* Opening a new workspace the default debug views sizes make sense 
* You can change size of each respective view and that size is preserved on reload

data.title: Syntax Highlighting in ES template strings inconsistent
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new JavaScript file
2. Paste the following code:

```js
const func1 = (path) => someFunc(`log some ${path}.`);
const func2 = (error) => someFunc(`log some ${error}.`);
```

For some reason the `path` variable is not blue whereas the `error` variable is. When I rename `path` to something else, it becomes blue. If I change it back, it is red again.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/875017/22789082/4acda07e-eee2-11e6-99fa-6816766acce9.png)

(In the screenshot I added a third line to check if the position within the file makes any difference)

Not really a big issue, but irritating :)


EDIT: I tested it without any extensions using `code --disable-extensions`. So I'm sure it's not an extension-related issue.

data.title: Quick fix menu pops up automatically when opening a file
Feature request: Make wrappingColumn setting available in showCommands list
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1

It would be nice to be able to quickly and dynamically change the `wrappingColumn` setting during editing by selecting it from the `showCommands` list (<kbd>F1</kbd> or <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>P</kbd>) and entering a new wrapping value.

data.title: Multi-Cursor Editing Collides with Windows 10 Screen Rotation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Multi-Cursor Editing states that you can press Ctrl+Alt+UpArrow or Ctrl+Alt+DownArrow to add a new cursor above or below. HOWEVER, Windows Windows 10 Screen Rotation hotkey is also Ctrl+Alt+Up so when I try to follow the instructions in VS CODE, my whole windows screen flips

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press Ctrl+Alt+Up or Ctrl+Alt+Down in Windows 10. The screen will flip. 

There may be ways to prevent this in Windows 10, but it sure is confusing if you have never seen this behavior before.

When you open a recent project from the welcome screen, the last one remains opened in a tab.

- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new VSCode window.
2. Open a recent project from the welcome screen.
3. The project is opened and the welcome screen remains opened.

data.title: node protocol probing confuses electron

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- Use this program test.js:
  ```js
  let i = 0;
  setInterval(() => {
	console.log('hello: ' + i++);
  }, 1000);
  ```
- download current Electron, e.g. on macOS https://github.com/electron/electron/releases/download/v1.4.15/electron-v1.4.15-darwin-x64.zip 
- run from command line with `./Electron.app/Contents/MacOS/Electron --debug=6009 test.js`
- attach VS Code with this config:
  ```json
  {
	"type": "node",
	"request": "attach",
	"name": "Attach to Process",
	"address": "localhost",
	"port": 6009,
	"protocol": "legacy"
  }
  ```

Observe: a debug session starts and if you set a breakpoint the program will stop and hit the breakpoint. 

- stop session
- change `protocol` to `auto`
- attach VS Code again

Observe: a message "Debugging with legacy protocol because Node version could not be determined." shows up in the debug console but no debug session starts.

Turning on tracing sends this to the debug console:
```json
Debugging with legacy protocol because Node version could not be determined.
62796: _attach: address: 127.0.0.1 port: 6009
62796: _attach: connected
62796: _terminated: socket end
62796: _terminated: node v8protocol close
62796: _terminated: socket error
62796: _terminated: node v8protocol error
62796: _terminated: node v8protocol error
62796: disconnectRequest: send response
```

So it looks like that the probing leaves the debug port in a strange state which prevents node-debug from connecting to that port successfully. 

When using 'node' instead of 'Electron', VS Code attaches successfully.

Trace output in this case:
```json
Debugging with legacy protocol because Node version could not be determined.
62843: _attach: address: 127.0.0.1 port: 6009
62843: _attach: connected
62843: _initialize: got process id 62839 from node
62843: _injectDebuggerExtensions: frame based code injection failed with error 'No frames'
62843: _injectDebuggerExtensions: global code injection successful
62843: _startInitialize: stopped: false
62843: _startInitialize: no entry event after 10 retries; giving up
62843: _startInitialize2: fire initialized event
62843: _startInitialize2: in attach mode we guess stopOnEntry flag to be 'false''
62843: _startInitialize2: remember to do a 'Continue' later
62843: setFunctionBreakPointsRequest: result []
62843: setExceptionBreakPointsRequest: ["uncaught"]
62843: configurationDoneRequest: do a 'Continue'
```

data.title: Debugging node breakpoints not working
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0-insider #1c1f82
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch node app with --debug or --debug-brk
2. Attach debugger

Debug console says **Debugging with legacy protocol because Node version could not be determined.** Break points not working. Has been doing this for a few days.

`debugger` statement works reliably. Breakpoints added through UI work inconsistently. I'm not able to determine what scenarios make them work or not work, but I just noticed the "legacy protocol" error today and assumed it was related.

Tried with node 5.5.0 and 6.9.5

data.title: Debug Actions Menu out of window boundaries
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start Debugging session.
2. Drag Debug Actions Menu more than maximum size of window to the left.
3. You cannot Drag and Drop it again, bacause Drag area is not vissible.
![screenshot_11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7376399/22787132/edd0aa90-eee3-11e6-84b0-448e915f15af.png)
![screenshot_12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7376399/22787133/edd1b764-eee3-11e6-9c08-a636ffaccf29.png)
![screenshot_13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7376399/22787131/edced68e-eee3-11e6-8c86-4c0d3c432fd2.png)

As you can see from the screenshots, when I resize the VSCode window, the Debug Actions Menu is appearing but yet, I cannot see Drag button :)

On fullscreen the menu is completely invisible.

data.title: Terminal encoding
data.body:
When I try to right some special chars on terminal it shows a code and not the special char. A list of characters examples are: `ç, é, ã, õ, í`

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Mac OS X Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the vscode internal terminal
2. Try to write any special characters

![vscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718366/22786590/e197df04-eeb7-11e6-9aa8-cd4db72bcf27.gif)

**UPDATE**: This happen not only when you try to write the characters but when try to render too when they appear on a `git diff` or `cat`

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: OSX Sierra 10.12.4 Beta

At this moment when you hit Ctrl + Tab to switch to another tab a dialog appears:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1002461/22784929/0d0ca1aa-eea0-11e6-91b6-eebfbdd76ff2.png)

I couldn't find an option to disable it.

It is possible to implement a configuration option to activate/disable it?

I am using Sublime Text Keymap

Thanks!

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have 2 or more tabs open
2. Press Ctrl + Tab
3. See Tab switching dialog

data.title: SSH connections with VS Code put my IP address on a blacklist (too many failed logins)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-08T23:31:51.320Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I open the built-in terminal.
2. I type my ssh command. I type the passphrase and type enter. The ssh connexion fails.
3. My website is not more accessible and my host informs me that my IP was blocked due to too many login attempts with ssh (IP blacklisted). On my request, my host unblocks my IP.
4. I try to connect via ssh with the standard terminal (MacOSX) and from there all is OK, the ssh connexion works.
5. When I try again from VS Code, the same problem appears: too many failed login attempts appears and IP blocked.

There is even a more bizarre behaviour: today, my IP was blocked after I launched VS Code, without any ssh connexion trial ! After having unblocked my IP, my host gave me the error message in its logs:

_csf.deny: 91.179.xxx.xxx # lfd: (sshd) Failed SSH login from 91.179.xxx.xxx (BE/Belgium/xxx.xxx-xxx-xx.adsl-dyn.isp.belgacom.be): 5 in the last 3600 secs - Thu Feb 9 11:15:12 2017_

And I din't try to connect via ssh. It is as if VS Code made attempts to connect via ssh autonomously and repeatedly when it is opened or when I type the ssh command. Here is the message that I see on my standard terminal after having succeeded to connect via ssh:

_Last failed login: Thu Feb  9 13:44:48 CET 2017 from 91.xxx.xxx.xxx on ssh:notty
There were 24 failed login attempts since the last successful login.
[user@world ~]$_

So there are 24 failed logins and I never made 24 attempts -> these attemps are automatic attempts.

Thank you in advance for your help.

data.title: feature request: use ctrl-n and ctrl-p to move in the explorer window
data.body:
Currently to select or move to next or previous items in the Explorer windows I have to use the mouse or arrow keys.

It would be great if I don't have to move my hand from keyboard move around the explorer window.  Ctrl-n for to move down and ctrl-p to move up would be great.
